awd_titl_txt: CUE Ethics: Collaborative Research: Open Collaborative Experiential Learning (OCEL.AI): Bridging Digital Divides in Undergraduate Education of Data Science
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of Missouri-Kansas City, in partnership with Eastern Michigan University, Essex County College, and University of Florida, proposes the Open Collaborative Experiential Learning (OCEL.AI) project, an Open Knowledge Network (OKN), that supports postsecondary instructors who teach underserved populations Computer Science (CS)+Journalism and Strategic Communication within their existing institutional structure. Recent advances in artificial intelligence (AI), and specifically deep learning (DL) have improved the state-of-the-art results of the data-driven approaches and tools in a wide range of domains. To build the future talent ecosystem, there is an urgent need to create a qualified data science workforce that can perform critical functions in a variety of domains and aspects of human society, such as journalism, health communication, and advertising. To address this need, the intelligent cloud-based collaborative tool will provide to the AI and data-driven research and education communities what GitHub and code repositories provide to the software engineering and open-source communities. In this OKN, minority students will feel empowered and motivated to study data science since they can share, reuse, reproduce, deploy, discuss, learn, and apply data and AI models in real time. It is expected that students taking these CS+Journalism and Strategic Communication courses will see increased interest, self-efficacy, and motivation in studying data science among both CS majors and non-majors - in particular among black, female, and Hispanic students. 

Organized as a Networked Improvement Community, the project will focus on three major tasks: 1) launching an online faculty professional development program on OCEL.AI that has been developed by the researcher's lab; 2) launching a student learning interface on OCEL.AI to offer engaging learning experiences to CS+Journalism and Strategic Communication students but also providing infrastructure that can be extended to CS+X programs for a range of other Xs such as business and health care; and 3) sparking critical thinking of data science ethics. To make data science more relevant to minority students, the project will highlight minority experiences in the United States by incorporating critical thinking around digital divides and data science ethics into the curriculum.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our Mission:

Open Collaborative Experiential Learning framework (OCEL.AI) features a storytelling approach to data science. It aims at broadening the participation in data science education by reaching and engaging more women and minorities in undergraduate education, especially those in the non-STEM fields. We aim to foster a keen interest in skills and careers in Data Science and motivate learning by incorporating critical thinking and data science ethics.

Our Approach:

  • Broadened reach to students via CS+X courses, with X being advertising, journalism, and communication.
  • Modularized OCEL.AI story-driven curriculum to support project-based learning and customization for different X disciplines and computer science courses.
  • Designed and developed www. OCEL.AI - a cloud-based AI learning and experience platform.
  • Developed and organized faculty training workshops to facilitate curriculum implementation.
  • Organized cross-campus interdisciplinary Hackathon competition to showcase students learning and achievements
  • Assessed students? learning outcomes of data science through surveys, experiments, interviews, and focus groups.

Our Research Questions:

  • CS courses, by incorporating OCEL.AI, increased the relevance, motivation, and self-efficacy to learn data science among female and minority undergraduate students who majored in Computer Science.
  • X courses, by incorporating OCEL.AI, increased the relevance, motivation, and self-efficacy in studying data science among students who are not computer science majors, particularly among female and minority undergraduate students.

Our Achievements:

  • A story-driven data science curriculum and practice sessions in various CS, Advertising, Communication, and Journalism classes at four institutions.
  • The implementation of data science training for faculty at four institutions.
  • Featuring students? projects through four Hackathon events across two years, a cross-campus and multidisciplinary open competition. In total, XX students in XX classes participated and demonstrated their projects.
  • Three peer-reviewed conference presentations, six peer-reviewed journal articles, three peer-reviewed journal articles that have been accepted for publication, and four articles that are currently under review in prestigious journals.
  • Students participating in the story-driven data science and AI program have reaped significant internship opportunities and career searching benefits.

 

Our Findings:

  • The storytelling approach appeals to a wide range of students. More than 50% of the student participants were from the race and ethnic minorities, and about 40% were women.
  • Courses in non-Computer Science disciplines serve as a good entry point, and bridge for women and minorities learn more advanced data science.
  • The storytelling approach is particularly effective for career motivation and confidence in conducting data cleaning.
  • The storytelling approach improves undergraduates? learning motivations and cognitive skills in data science. STEM students recognize that data scientists need to tell good stories and non-STEM students realize the relevance of storytelling to data science.

Last Modified: 10/03/2022
Modified by: Yugyung S Lee

por.por_txt_cntn:
Our Mission:
Open Collaborative Experiential Learning framework (OCEL.AI) features a storytelling approach to data science. It aims at broadening the participation in data science education by reaching and engaging more women and minorities in undergraduate education, especially those in the non-STEM fields. We aim to foster a keen interest in skills and careers in Data Science and motivate learning by incorporating critical thinking and data science ethics.

Our Approach:

Broadened reach to students via CS+X courses, with X being advertising, journalism, and communication.
Modularized OCEL.AI story-driven curriculum to support project-based learning and customization for different X disciplines and computer science courses.
Designed and developed www. OCEL.AI - a cloud-based AI learning and experience platform. 
Developed and organized faculty training workshops to facilitate curriculum implementation. 
Organized cross-campus interdisciplinary Hackathon competition to showcase students learning and achievements
Assessed students? learning outcomes of data science through surveys, experiments, interviews, and focus groups. 


Our Research Questions:

CS courses, by incorporating OCEL.AI, increased the relevance, motivation, and self-efficacy to learn data science among female and minority undergraduate students who majored in Computer Science.
X courses, by incorporating OCEL.AI, increased the relevance, motivation, and self-efficacy in studying data science among students who are not computer science majors, particularly among female and minority undergraduate students.


Our Achievements:

A story-driven data science curriculum and practice sessions in various CS, Advertising, Communication, and Journalism classes at four institutions.
The implementation of data science training for faculty at four institutions. 
Featuring students? projects through four Hackathon events across two years, a cross-campus and multidisciplinary open competition. In total, XX students in XX classes participated and demonstrated their projects. 
Three peer-reviewed conference presentations, six peer-reviewed journal articles, three peer-reviewed journal articles that have been accepted for publication, and four articles that are currently under review in prestigious journals. 
Students participating in the story-driven data science and AI program have reaped significant internship opportunities and career searching benefits. 


 

Our Findings:

The storytelling approach appeals to a wide range of students. More than 50% of the student participants were from the race and ethnic minorities, and about 40% were women.
Courses in non-Computer Science disciplines serve as a good entry point, and bridge for women and minorities learn more advanced data science.
The storytelling approach is particularly effective for career motivation and confidence in conducting data cleaning. 
The storytelling approach improves undergraduates? learning motivations and cognitive skills in data science. STEM students recognize that data scientists need to tell good stories and non-STEM students realize the relevance of storytelling to data science.
